:''Note: For the [[African American]] [[civil rights]] activist, see [[Ella Baker]]''. {{More footnotes|date=March 2010}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = Etta Baker | image = Ettabakerphoto.jpg | caption = Etta Baker with acoustic guitar | image_size = | background = solo_singer | birth_name = Etta Lucille Reid | alias = | birth_date = {{Birth date|1913|3|31}} | death_date = {{death date and age|2006|9|23|1913|3|31}}
[[Fairfax, Virginia|Fairfax]], [[Virginia]], [[United States]] | origin = [[Caldwell County, North Carolina|Caldwell County]], [[North Carolina]], [[United States]] | instrument = [[Guitar]]
[[Banjo]]
[[Human voice|Vocals]] | genre = [[Piedmont blues]]
[[Country blues]] | occupation = | years_active = | label = [[Rounder Records|Rounder]], [[Tradition Records|Tradition]], [[Reprise Records|Reprise]], [[Music Maker (label)|Music Maker]] | associated_acts = | website = | current_members = | past_members = | notable_instruments = }} '''Etta Baker''' (March 31, 1913 – September 23, 2006) was an [[United States|American]] [[Piedmont blues]] guitarist and singer from [[North Carolina]], [[United States]]. ==Biography== She was born '''Etta Lucille Reid''' in [[Caldwell County, North Carolina|Caldwell County]], [[North Carolina]], of [[African American]], [[Native Americans in the United States|Native American]], and European American heritage.http://www.cdbaby.com/cd/ettacora Etta Baker and Cora Phillips She played both the 6-string and [[Twelve string guitar|12-string]] forms of the [[Steel-string guitar|acoustic guitar]], as well as the five-string [[banjo]]. Baker played the Piedmont Blues for ninety years, starting at the age of three when she could not even hold the guitar properly. She was taught by her father, Boone Reid, who was also a longtime player of the Piedmont Blues on several instruments. Etta Baker was first recorded in the summer of 1956 when she and her father happened across folk singer [[Paul Clayton (folksinger)|Paul Clayton]] while visiting Cone Mansion in [[Blowing Rock, North Carolina]], near their home in Morganton, NC. Baker's father asked Clayton to listen to his daughter playing her signature "One Dime Blues". Clayton was impressed and arrived at the Baker house with his tape recorder the next day, recording several songs.{{cite book|last1=Coltman|first1=Bob|title=Paul Clayton and the Folksong Revival|publisher=Scarecrow Press|year=2008|location=Lanham, Maryland|pages=297|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=UAn-54_ogxcC&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false|accessdate=2011-02-12|isbn=0-8108-6132-1}} Over the years, Baker has shared her knowledge with many well known musical artists including [[Bob Dylan]], [[Taj Mahal (musician)|Taj Mahal]], and [[Kenny Wayne Shepherd]]. Baker received the [[North Carolina Folk Heritage Award]] from the [[North Carolina Arts Council]] in 1989, the [[National Endowment for the Arts]]' [[National Heritage Fellowship]] in 1991, and the [[North Carolina Award]] in 2003. Along with her sister, Cora Phillips, Baker received the [[North Carolina Folklore Society]]'s Brown-Hudson Folklore Award in 1982.[http://www.ecu.edu/ncfolk/brownhud.htm Ecu.edu/ncfolk] Baker had nine children, one of whom was killed in the [[Vietnam War]] in 1967, the same year her husband died. She last lived in [[Morganton, North Carolina]], and died at the age of 93 in [[Fairfax, Virginia]], while visiting a daughter who had suffered a stroke. ==Discography== * 1956 : ''Instrumental Music From the Southern Appalachians'' (1956, [[Tradition Records]]; reissued 1997) * 1990 : ''One Dime Blues'' * 1998 : ''The North Carolina Banjo Collection'' (various artists) (1998, Rounder) * 1999 : ''Railroad Bill'' * 2004 : ''Etta Baker with [[Taj Mahal (musician)|Taj Mahal]]'' ([[Music Maker (label)|Music Maker]] 50) * 2005 : ''Carolina Breakdown'' with [[Cora Phillips]] ([[Music Maker (label)|Music Maker]] 56) * 2006 : ''Knoxville Rag'' with [[Kenny Wayne Shepherd]] (CD Title: "10 Days Out- Blues From The Backroads", it also includes a DVD that shows Kenny & Etta playing guitar in her kitchen), Reprise Records, 2006. {{UPC|093624929420}} ===Obituaries=== *[http://www.newsobserver.com/100/story/490622.html Etta Baker obituary] from ''The News & Observer''
